title: Typography
description: Use typography to make writing legible and beautiful. Material's default type scale includes contrasting and flexible styles to support a wide range of use cases.

contentChunks.altText: Type at different scales

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
Design
Design kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – TypographyAvailable
Google FontsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeIn progress
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Variable fonts are a new technology offering more typographic control
  • There are five key type styles: Display, headline, title, body, and label
  • Design tokens help scale typography decisions across devices, including font, line height, size, tracking, and weight
What's new

Variable fonts

Roboto Flex and Roboto Serif

Updated considerations for using variable fonts and their customizable axes includes Grade, Width, and Optical Size

contentChunks.footer: Roboto Flex and Roboto Serif have a fluid range of weight, from extremely thin to extremely bold styles in the larger optical sizes.
contentChunks.altText: Roboto Flex and Roboto Serif type rendered in two different weights

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Five type styles

Type styles are defined by five roles: Display, headline, title, body, and label.

These new roles are more descriptive, allowing for simpler application across a broader range of use cases.

contentChunks.footer: M3 has five distinct type styles: Display, headline, title, body, and label.
contentChunks.altText: Different examples of Roboto scaled to their respective roles: Display, headline, title, body, and label

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Typography tokens

While earlier iterations of Material relied on hard-coded style values for typography, design tokens offer an improved way to define typography in products. Tokens assign an element's type style by a configurable value, rather than a set value. 

Type roles describe size—such as small, medium, and large—enabling them to adapt and respond to the device or context.

contentChunks.footer: Typography tokens describe scalable size that adapts to devices or settings.
contentChunks.altText: Close crop of markdown text showing type scales referenced as “display-large” and “display-medium”

contentChunks.htmlValue: Default typefaces

The default typeface for Android is Roboto.

Roboto includes over 3,300 glyphs for representing hundreds of languages around the world.

For additional typographic flexibility, try its variable font successor, Roboto Flex. This has an extended range of weights, widths, and additional customizable attributes (like size-specific designs) and also includes over 900 glyphs with support for Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic.

contentChunks.footer: Roboto Flex includes the styles of Roboto plus many more weights and widths optimized for larger and smaller sizes.
contentChunks.altText: A type specimen of Roboto and Roboto Flex

contentChunks.htmlValue: Roboto Serif is another variable font family, designed to create a comfortable reading experience. Minimal and highly functional, it can be used anywhere (even in app interfaces) due to its extensive set of weights and widths across a broad range of sizes.

contentChunks.footer: Roboto Serif offers a functional set of weights and widths.
contentChunks.altText: A type specimen of Roboto Serif

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Noto is a global font collection for all modern and ancient languages.

Each Noto Sans family is compatible with Roboto and Noto Sans supports more than 150 scripts and thousands of languages. It is used as a “fallback” font, when a language is unsupported.

Learn more about typography language considerations.

contentChunks.footer: Several Noto Sans fonts for different writing systems.
contentChunks.altText: A type specimen of several Noto Sans fonts

contentChunks.htmlValue: Type scale

A type scale is a selection of font styles that can be used across an app, ensuring a flexible, yet consistent, style that accommodates a range of purposes. The Material Design type scale is a combination of 15 styles, each with an intended application and meaning. They’re assigned based on use (such as display or headline), and grouped more broadly into categories based on scale (such as large or small). Material Design’s default type scale uses Roboto for all titles, labels, and body text, creating a cohesive typography experience.

Get started customizing Material's baseline type scale in the Material Theme Builder (Figma).

contentChunks.footer: The scale is a range of contrasting styles that support the needs of various product contexts and content. No single product will use all the styles defined below. Instead, select styles from the scale that are most appropriate.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of the M3 type scale

The Material Design typescale distinguishes between two types of reference tokens: brand and plain. This enables you to use two different typefaces within your design. The brand typeface (which has the token md.ref.typeface.brand) is recommended for larger font sizes, such as Headline and Display, while plain typeface (with the token md.ref.typeface.plain) is suitable for smaller font sizes, such as Body and Label.
Customizing your type scale

When different sizes from the defaults are needed, such as for different devices, you can customize the type scale by adding or removing styles, and even swapping out Roboto for a font of your choice.
Material Design uses the Major Second type scale with 14 as its key base size. This anchors to the most essential style used most often for typesetting body text.

contentChunks.footer: The Material Design type scale uses the Major Second scale (1.125).
contentChunks.altText: The major second scale, showing type sizes from 103 to 10

contentChunks.htmlValue: Sizes on the rendered type scale should aim to provide impactful contrast between sizes by avoiding small differences.

contentChunks.footer: Material’s default typescale of fifteen styles.
contentChunks.altText: Material Design’s default type scale; showing display, headline, and title sizes shown next to the Major Second type scale

contentChunks.footer: Your product likely will not need all 15 default styles from the Material Design type scale. In this example, five sizes are chosen for a reduced set while the rest are removed.
contentChunks.altText: Display, headline, and title sizes shown next to the Major Second type scale

contentChunks.footer: If the default sizes from the Material Design type scale do not meet your needs, values can be substituted instead. Here the default display medium size is adjusted to another size from the Major Second type scale.
contentChunks.altText: A size modification of Material Design’s default type scale where display medium is a larger size than the original scale

contentChunks.htmlValue:
To customize with your own typography, begin by applying your selected typefaces to the existing styles, matching type size and weight.  

From there, adjust line height and letter spacing values to accommodate the unique features of your custom typeface. Heavier fonts may require wider letter spacing, while fonts with long ascenders and descenders will require different line heights.

contentChunks.footer: Custom typefaces can create an expressive, unique expression in your app.
contentChunks.altText: Example type scales with custom typefaces and weights

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Font size units

The following units are used to express font size on Android and the web.

PlatformAndroidWeb
Font size unitsprem
Conversion ratio1.00.0625

Web browsers calculate the REM (the root em size) based on the root element size. The default for modern web browsers is 16px, so the conversion is SP_SIZE/16 = rem.

Example conversions

AndroidWeb
10sp0.625rem
12sp0.75rem
24sp1.5rem
60sp3.75rem

Letter spacing units

The following units are for spacing letters in a UI.

Platform
Android
Web
Letter spacing unit
emrem
Conversion ratio
(Tracking value in px / font size in sp) = letter spacing(Tracking value in px / font size in sp) = letter spacing

Letter spacing examples

AndroidWeb
(.2 tracking / 16sp font size) = 0.0125 em(.2 tracking / 16px font size) = 0.0125 rem
Adjustable axes

While variable fonts can have a multitude of variable font attributes for expression, there are four customizable stylistic attributes (or axes) that are most applicable for product design: weight, grade, width, and optical size.

Weight

Weight is the primary attribute that defines the overall thickness of a typeface’s strokes in any given font. The most common weights are regular and bold, but weights can cover extremes from the very light to the very heavy. 

If the typeface is variable, it provides a full, continuous range of stroke thicknesses, making the number of weights effectively unlimited. 

Learn more about weight on Google Fonts.

contentChunks.footer: A variable font, Roboto Flex offers a fluid range of weights.
contentChunks.altText: Many examples of Roboto Flex weights.

contentChunks.footer: Be careful of using excessively lighter weight type for body text. Lower resolution displays can struggle with rendering more delicate typography, especially at small sizes. Instead, consider lighter weights at larger font sizes, such as display type.
contentChunks.altText: Light text in use as body text

contentChunks.footer: Excessive weight at smaller sizes may affect legibility.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar using bold typography for label text, making it challenging to read

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Grade

Grade is a secondary modifier of a typeface’s optical weight, independent of the weight axis. Both weight and grade axes affect a letter’s thickness, but adjustments with grade are much more granular and don’t change any letter widths or line breaks.

Learn more about grade on Google Fonts.

contentChunks.footer: Roboto Flex offers a positive grade of 150 and a negative grade of 200.
contentChunks.altText: Three ampersands set in Roboto Flex without grade over Roboto Flex with 150 grade

contentChunks.footer: When switching between dark and light mode, the same text may appear heavier despite having the same settings. Consider using a negative grade to counteract this.
contentChunks.altText: A light and dark screen each showing the letter B.

contentChunks.footer: Grade can change the emphasis without reflowing text.
contentChunks.altText: A list of amenities where the filter chip for “Elevator” and “Cats OK” are selected and have a heavier grade applied.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Width

Width is the result of how much horizontal space is taken up by a typeface’s characters. 

A narrow width allows more characters to fit per line while a wider width may offer more personality. 

Learn more about width on Google Fonts.

contentChunks.footer: Roboto Flex offers a fluid range of widths, from 25 to 150.
contentChunks.altText: The letter ‘N’, set in Roboto Flex, rendered in varying widths

contentChunks.footer: A thinner width can allow for more characters to fit at small sizes, such as in a label.
contentChunks.altText: A bottom navigation bar with four icons using narrow label text under the icons

contentChunks.footer: Since wider styles take up more space, avoid using them for areas with limited space, such as in a top app bar.
contentChunks.altText: Top app bar with the title best thrift stores in wide type next to three icons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Optical size

Optical sizes are different versions of a typeface optimized for use at different sizes.

Small size designs focus on enhancing readability, while large size designs can show off the intricacies of the letterforms and offer many more weights and widths. 

Learn about choosing typefaces that have optical sizes.

contentChunks.footer: The typeface Literata has a continuous range of optical size, from 7pt to 72pt.
contentChunks.altText: The word hello at a small optical size overlaid over the word hello at a large optical size

contentChunks.footer: Use an optical size that matches your type size.
contentChunks.altText: The words “massive” and “tiny” with optical sizes that match their type size

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use large optical type sizes at small sizes. Instead use a smaller optical size, if available.
contentChunks.altText: Two paragraphs of text set with an optical size larger than the type size

contentChunks.htmlValue: Applying type

Hierarchy is communicated through differences in font weight, size, line height, and letter spacing. The updated type scale organizes styles into five roles that are named to describe their purposes: Display, headline, title, label, body. The new roles are device-agnostic, allowing easier application across a variety of use cases.
Roles

Display

There are three display styles in the default type scale: Large, medium, and small. As the largest text on the screen, display styles are reserved for short, important text or numerals. They work best on large screens.

For display type, consider choosing a more expressive font, such as a handwritten or script style. 

If available, set the appropriate optical size to your usage.

contentChunks.footer: An expressive typeface can be used for display styles.
contentChunks.altText: Example display typeface

contentChunks.footer: A card using a display size.
contentChunks.altText: Card featuring display size font

contentChunks.footer: An expressive typeface can entice readers to engage with an eye-catching design.
contentChunks.altText: Large expressive typeface set above text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Headline

Headlines are best-suited for short, high-emphasis text on smaller screens. These styles can be good for marking primary passages of text or important regions of content.

Headlines can also make use of expressive typefaces, provided that appropriate line height and letter spacing is also integrated to maintain readability.

contentChunks.footer: Expressive typefaces can be used for headlines styles as well.
contentChunks.altText: Example expressive headline typeface on phone screen

contentChunks.footer: Headline style used for short text on a small screen.
contentChunks.altText: The name Ana Russo in headline style in a contact card

contentChunks.footer: Dialog using a headline style.
contentChunks.altText: Headline style set above body text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Title

Titles are smaller than headline styles, and should be used for medium-emphasis text that remains relatively short. For example, consider using title styles to divide secondary passages of text or secondary regions of content.

For titles, use caution when using expressive fonts, including display, handwritten, and script styles.

contentChunks.footer: A news article title using the title style to capture attention.
contentChunks.altText: An article card using title style for the article title

contentChunks.footer: Top app bar using title style.
contentChunks.altText: Top app bar using title style for the contact name, Aki Aro

contentChunks.footer: Example of title style applied to a category header: Top News.
contentChunks.altText: Title style stating ‘Top News’ above headlines

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Body

Body styles are used for longer passages of text in your app. 

Use typefaces intended for body styles, which are readable at smaller sizes and can be comfortably read in longer passages.

Avoid expressive or decorative fonts for body text because these can be harder to read at small sizes.

contentChunks.footer: Body styles must be readable for long passages.
contentChunks.altText: Body-style typeface

contentChunks.footer: Body style used throughout an article about pesto.
contentChunks.altText: Body style text in  article

contentChunks.footer: Example of body style used throughout a setup flow.
contentChunks.altText: Three stacked examples of body style in app setup flow

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label

Label styles are smaller, utilitarian styles, used for things like the text inside components or for very small text in the content body, such as captions. 

Buttons, for example, use the label large style.

contentChunks.footer: Label styles should enable quick reading at small sizes, such as in buttons.
contentChunks.altText: Several label-style buttons on device screen.

contentChunks.footer: A music player using label style for the timecode.
contentChunks.altText: Music player timecode featuring label style

contentChunks.footer: A navigation bar using label style for the destination text.
contentChunks.altText: Five labels set horizontally across the navigation bar

contentChunks.htmlValue: Typesetting

Vertical typesetting relies on padding, bounding boxes, and baselines to ensure text legibility at any size. 

Take engineering considerations and the conventions of your platform into account when making decisions for typesetting, text resizing, density, and using text in adaptive layouts.

Using padding and bounding boxes

Use this method for web products, and iOS products, where applicable. Note that some design tools also use bounding boxes for typesetting, but their methods vary and will need to be reconciled with the engineering implementation.

In web UIs, the line height and bounding box height are the same. Text is vertically centered within the bounding box, following the “half-leading” behavior established by CSS.

The vertical position of the text isn’t controlled directly, but through the combination of the bounding box and font metrics.

contentChunks.footer: The bounding box height is defined by the line height specified, with equal space placed above and below the text.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of bounding box equaling line height

contentChunks.htmlValue: Padding is the space between UI elements, such as between an image and a bounding box, or between the inner edge of the bounding box and the text.

contentChunks.footer: The padding surrounding the text bounding box.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 20 dp padding above text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Specify the distance of UI elements from fixed reference points, such as the container edge. For the web, automate this calculation using Sass or CSS.

contentChunks.footer: Use line-height, padding, and container measurements for setting typography on the web and iOS. If you develop for the web, you can directly use values via the code inspector in Figma, Gallery, or Markup.
contentChunks.altText: Overline and caption style text in Google Sans Text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Vertical alignment using padding and bounding boxes:

  1. Line height
    Measure the height of the bounding box.
  2. Centering
    Ensure equal top and bottom padding around the inner edge of the bounding box by using center align
  3. Spacing
    Use the height of the bounding box, and top and bottom padding to determine spacing.

contentChunks.altText: Diagram of using padding and bounding boxes to measure line height, alignment, and spacing

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Using the baseline

Use this method for Android products or platform-agnostic specs.
The baseline is the invisible line upon which a line of text rests. In Material Design, the baseline is an important specification in measuring the vertical distance between text and an element.

contentChunks.footer: A line of text rests on the invisible baseline.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram indicating the baseline of text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
For Android, specifying distances relative to baseline enables accurate implementation.

The baseline can also be used to communicate text position between designers in a way that's agnostic to the platform or design tool.

contentChunks.footer: Android screens rely on distance to baselines for spacing.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of the distances between overline and container edge, plus subhead, overline, and caption text

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Vertical alignment using baseline

  1. Line height
    Measure distance from the text baseline of one line to the text baseline of the next line.
  2. Centering
    Specify center alignment as a reference instead of measuring the distance to the text baseline.
  3. Spacing
    Use the distance from a reference point to the text baseline.

contentChunks.altText: Diagram of using distance to baseline to measure line height, alignment, and spacing

contentChunks.htmlValue: Ensuring readability

Line length

Line length is how many characters are on a single line of text. 

For longer body text, the recommended line length is between 40 to 60 characters.

For shorter lines of text, the ideal length is 20 to 40 characters.

contentChunks.footer: For longer lines of English text, the ideal line length is 40–60 characters per line.
contentChunks.altText: Range of longer text lengths from 0 to 90 characters per line, with ideal set at 40–60 characters per line

contentChunks.footer: For shorter lines of English text, the ideal line length is 20–40 characters per line.
contentChunks.altText: Range of shorter text lengths from 0 to 50 characters per line, with ideal set at 20–40 characters per line

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Line height

Line height is the space between each line of text and is directly connected to type size.

Material’s type tokens are optimized for intended size and use.

contentChunks.footer: For larger type legibility using styles like title, headline, and display, we recommend a line height ratio of 1.2 times the type size.
contentChunks.altText: An example of larger type with a line height ratio of 1.2

contentChunks.footer: For smaller body copy using styles like body and label, we recommend a line height ratio around 1.5 times the type size. If your line height is too tight, you’ll undermine the flow of the text. Too loose, and the lines won’t feel cohesive.
contentChunks.altText: An example of body type with a line height ratio of 1.5

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tabular numbers 

 Use tabular figures (also known as monospaced numbers) rather than proportional digits in tables or places where values may change often, such as clocks.

Use monospaced tabular numbers to keep values optically aligned for better scanning.

contentChunks.footer: 1. Proportional numbers, 2. Monospaced tabular numbers
contentChunks.altText: Vertical view showing the spacing variation in proportional numbers versus monospacing of tabular numbers

contentChunks.footer: Use tabular numbers to prevent layout shifting when values change, such as in a clock UI.
contentChunks.altText: Times displayed in tabular numbers

contentChunks.htmlValue: Using Material Symbols with typography

Material Symbols are designed with similar considerations to typefaces, and often appear alongside text. Choosing the right icon set can tie the content of an interface together, enhancing the cohesive branded feel of your product.

contentChunks.footer: Use the same size for your Material Symbols and text.
contentChunks.altText: Symbol and text with the same weight

contentChunks.footer: Don’t mix the sizes of your symbol and text.
contentChunks.altText: Symbol shown in smaller size than text

contentChunks.footer: Use the same weight for your symbol and text.
contentChunks.altText: Symbol and text with same weight

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use the different weights for Material Symbols and text.
contentChunks.altText: Symbol and text with different weights

contentChunks.footer: Shift down the baseline of symbols to approximately 11.5% of the text size.
contentChunks.altText: Baseline symbol set lower than text baseline

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use the same baseline for Material Symbols and text.
contentChunks.altText: Material Symbol and text sharing the same baseline

contentChunks.htmlValue: Accessibility

Color & contrast

Support visual accessibility by choosing the appropriate color contrast between your product’s text and background. Contrast is the perceived difference between the lightness or darkness of two colors, and is quantified by a contrast ratio. Key contrast ratios indicate levels of contrast that are sufficient for accessibility. 

Learn more about contrast and accessibility.

contentChunks.altText: Contrast between two colors, quantified by a contrast ratio, supports visual accessibility.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Text should achieve sufficient contrast between its color and that of its background. Sufficient contrast depends on the size of the text and the level of accessibility required. 

Learn more about contrast requirements for text.

contentChunks.altText: Large text should achieve a contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for AAA-level accessibility
Small text should achieve a contrast ratio of 7:1 for AAA-level accessibility

contentChunks.htmlValue: The default color for typography is on surface, although on surface variant is a strong alternative.

contentChunks.footer: Default typography colors

contentChunks.htmlValue: Scaling type

Maintain hierarchy and scaling across devices by modifying certain elements as you scale.

Scaling from watch to mobile: Increase the size of headlines, display, and body.

Scaling from mobile or tablet to desktop: Increase the size of display and headline.

contentChunks.footer:
Roles of the same name can scale with the device size.
1. Display
2. Body

contentChunks.htmlValue: When scaling between a desktop and TV display, increase the size of headlines and body type.

contentChunks.footer:
Tablet (left) and desktop (right) both use:
1. Headline
2. Body

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Multi-column scaling

As your layout adapts to different device sizes, consider maintaining the focus of an area by increasing the type size of that element. This example shows a column configuration scaling from a closed mobile device to an unfolded mobile device. The most prominent card (1) scales to maintain hierarchy.
